key_title: Key to the species of Hydrocotyle

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Araliaceae

source.author: Duretto, M.F.
source.title: Apiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Duretto, M.F. (1999). Apiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves peltately attached; inflorescences either interrupted spikes or compound umbels
Leaves not peltately attached (leaf-bases often cordate); inflorescences either simple umbels or small heads
Inflorescence a compound umbel, flowers distinctly pedicellate
Inflorescence a simple umbel or an umbel subtended by 1-several whorls, appearing spike-like, sometimes branched; flowers subsessile
Perennial prostrate or climbing herbs; stems to more than 1 m long, creeping, usually rooting at nodes
Annual erect or semi-erect herbs to 12 cm high; stems not creeping, not rooting at nodes
Fruit with a fringe of long, spreading white hairs near apex
Fruit glabrous
Mericarps smooth (but with a single pit or pocket on each lateral face)
Mericarps with prominent ridges or several reticulate ridges between dorsal and intermediate ribs
All or most umbels distinctly pedunculate; mericarps blackish, pouched (not white-rimmed) beside the intermediate rib on each face
All or most umbels sessile (terminal ones often pedunculate); mericarps reddish-brown with a deep, white-rimmed pit on each face
Dorsal and intermediate ribs connected by 2–7 blunt thick ridges with deep depressions between them
Area between dorsal and intermediate ribs reticulated with small, interconnecting ridges
Dorsal and intermediate ribs connected by 5–7 ridges forming 6–7 deep depressions; base of each depression smooth
Dorsal and intermediate ribs connected by 2–3 ridges forming 3–4 deep depressions; each depression with a white protuberance at base
Umbels 3–6-flowered; mericarps smooth between intermediate ribs
Umbels (3–) 6–12-flowered; mericarp pitted between intermediate ribs
Leaves palmately divided (sometimes entire leaves also present)
Leaves entire, but sometimes deeply lobed
Leaves 3–10 cm across; leaflets lanceolate, toothed; pedicels 2–3 mm long
Leaves to 2.5 cm across; leaflets cuneate, entire, or 3–5-toothed or apex toothed; pedicels to 0.5 mm long
Leaflets 5
Leaflets 3, outer 2 often deeply divided
Petioles with reflexed hairs and abaxial leaflet surface strigose; median leaflet obovate
Petioles and abaxial leaflet surface glabrous; median leaflet orbicular
Fruit 4–5 mm wide; dorsal rib of mericarp prominently winged
Fruit 1–2.5 mm wide; dorsal rib of mericarp not prominently winged
Umbel open; pedicels 5–8 mm long; flowers usually unisexual, often with a strong offensive odour
Umbel tightly packed; pedicels to 3.5 mm long; flowers bisexual, without an offensive odour or weakly odorous
Umbels usually with 15 or more sessile or subsessile flowers (rarely pedicels to 1.3 mm long in H. hirta); leaf margin finely serrate, crenate-dentate or crenate; fruits usually dark brown when ripe

Umbels usually with fewer than 15 flowers (or if ever 15 per umbel as sometimes in H. algida (confined to subalpine and alpine areas) and H. acutiloba (eastern Victoria), then pedicels to 2.5 mm long and or leaf lobes acute); leaf margin crenate or coarsely dentate; fruits usually yellowish to olive brown when ripe
Leaf margin finely serrate; petals white, creamish white,  or white suffused with red in upper ½; mericarps not red-dotted
Leaf margin crenate to crenate-dentate; petals pale yellow and usually red-dotted; mericarps usually red-dotted
Lobes of leaves acute; peduncle never as long as petiole
Lobes of leaves obtuse, truncate or rounded; peduncle shorter, equal to or longer than petiole
Leaf margin finely serrate; flowers sessile to subsessile; petals white, creamish white, or white suffused with red in upper ½
Leaf margin crenate; pedicels to 3.5 mm long; petals light yellow green or yellow-white
Adaxial surface of leaves hirsute with short, curved hairs; petiole usually hairy throughout
Adaxial surface of leaves (and sometimes entire plant) glabrous, or with few, fine, bristle-like hairs; petiole often with a 'frill' of deflexed hairs just below leaf-lamina, otherwise glabrous
